Motivation
Collatz conjecture Collatz mapping The development of this package has originally been inspired by the famous 3n+1-Conjecture. This conjecture asserts that iterated application of the Collatz mapping
T: \ \Z \longrightarrow \Z, \ \ \ \ n \ \longmapsto \ \begin{cases} \frac{n}{2} & \text{if} \ n \ \text{even}, \\ \frac{3n+1}{2} & \text{if} \ n \ \text{odd} \end{cases}
/ | n/2 if n even, T: Z -> Z, n |-> < | (3n+1)/2 if n odd \
to any given positive integer eventually yields 1.
The 3n+1-Conjecture has been made by Lothar Collatz in the 1930s, and is still lacking a proof today. Jeffrey C. Lagarias has written and maintains a comprehensive annotated bibliography , which currently lists about 200 references to publications related to Collatz' conjecture. None of the articles mentioned there tries to attack the problem by means of group theory or investigates the structure of groups generated by bijective mappings which are similar to the Collatz mapping, i.e. residue class-wise affine. In fact, residue class-wise affine groups apparently have not been treated anywhere in the literature before.
After having investigated these objects for a couple of years, the author feels that this is a gap which is worth to be filled.

Groups which can be represented
This section lists some types of groups which are known to be representable as residue class-wise affine groups. Proofs of most of the results have not yet appeared in print, but can be found in preprints on the author's homepage.
Obviously, the infinite dihedral group \langle n \mapsto -n, n \mapsto n+1 \rangle can be represented. Further the class of representable groups is closed under forming wreath products with finite groups (cp. , Corollary 2.3.3 and Theorem 2.6.1) and with the infinite cyclic group (\Z,+). Free groups and free products of finite groups can be represented as well. Further there are divisible torsion groups and finitely generated groups with unsolvable membership problem which have faithful residue class-wise affine representations. In principle this package permits to construct and investigate groups of all mentioned types.
The group which is generated by all class transpositions -- these are involutions which interchange two disjoint residue classes, see -- is a simple group which contains all the above groups. It has uncountably many simple subgroups.

Purpose of this package
So far, compared to classes of groups like for example matrix groups, finite permutation groups or polycyclic groups, only relatively basic facts about residue class-wise affine groups are known. This package is intended to serve as a tool for obtaining a better understanding of their rich and interesting group theoretical and combinatorial structure.
This manual is pure software documentation, and as such it does not contain any theorems or proofs. Mathematical assertions are usually only made in places where they are necessary for understanding the functionality of this package. Proofs of many of them as well as a detailed introduction into the subject can be found in the author's PhD thesis . A copy of this thesis and an english translation thereof are distributed with this package (see thesis/thesis.pdf resp. thesis/thesis&uscore;e.pdf).

Scope of this package
This package being a research tool which can be applied in various ways to various different problems, it is simply not possible to say what can be found out with it about which mappings or groups. The best way to get an idea about this is likely to experiment with the examples discussed in this manual and included in the file pkg/rcwa/examples/examples.g. Another source of examples is the Random - function. If you have &LaTeX; and xdvi installed, you can nicely display examples of residue class-wise affine mappings by repeatedly issueing Display(Random(RCWA(Integers)):xdvi);.
Of course this package often does not provide an out-of-the-box solution for a given problem. At the beginning you may perhaps notice extremely long runtimes for seemingly easy things. But with some experience you will learn to estimate how long something will take and to see why raising some harmlessly-looking mapping to the 20th power would take terabytes of memory, while one can easily find out nontrivial things about groups which look much more complicate. Quite often it is possible to find an answer for a given question by using an interactive trial-and-error approach.
Among many other results, with substancial help of this package the author has found a proof that the group generated by all class transpositions is simple. Interactive sessions with this package have also lead to the development of a method for factoring residue class-wise affine permutations into involutions which have a particularly simple structure (see ).
